docs.lead_paragraph: I wouldn't blame Senator Charles Schumer for growing bored with Washington. The restaurants are mediocre, the architecture is sterile, the streets fold up at night and the commute from Brooklyn is a nightmare. I've avoided the place myself for years. But if he's thinking about giving up his Senate seat and running for governor of New York State, there are a few things he needs to consider.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by WCBS-TV reporter Andrew Kirtzman suggests New York Sen Charles Schumer reconsider running for governor (M)
docs.snippet: I wouldn't blame Senator Charles Schumer for growing bored with Washington. The restaurants are mediocre, the architecture is sterile, the streets fold up at night and the commute from Brooklyn is a nightmare. I've avoided the place myself for years....

docs.lead_paragraph: Christina Irene Tobin, a daughter of Gail and Joseph G. Tobin of Kent, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. David Matthew Krol, the son of Therese and Andrew J. Krol of North Ridgeville, Ohio. The Rev. Thomas E. Berberich performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Kent. Mrs. Krol, 27, is a production associate for ''Primetime Live'' at ABC News in New York. She graduated from Hamilton College. Her father is the chairman of the Nicholas/Tobin Insurance Company in New Milford, Conn. The bride's maternal grandfather, the late Roger E. Lewis, was chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, the military contractor, and the first president of Amtrak.

AMERICAN politicians are so perplexed about how to deal with prescription drug prices that the best solution they can offer is to effectively import a Canadian law -- by buying drugs subject to Canadian government price controls -- rather than pass one of their own. There are, however, more straightforward ways to get cheaper drugs than by borrowing price fixes from across the border. Some economists say the government can reduce pharmaceutical prices by changing how the nation pays for innovation.

headline.main: Do New Drugs Always Have to Cost So Much?

docs.abstract: Analysis of question of why new prescription drugs cost so much; notes that they are expensive to invent, but relatively cheap to make; says companies receive patents from government that grant them monopoly and enable them to sell medicine at premium; notes some economists say that there is no inexorable economic reason for drug prices to be as high as they are; chart; graph; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Some economists say the government can reduce pharmaceutical prices by changing how the nation pays for innovation.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey's largest health insurer, Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield, has announced that a computer error caused more than 600 physicians to be overpaid for heart procedures and have asked the doctors to give back nearly $15 million dollars. The payments, which date back nearly two years, were paid above contracted rates for reimbursement for cardiac catheterization procedures, a company spokesman said. John Holl
docs.abstract: Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey announces that computer error caused more than 600 doctors to be overpaid for cardiac catherization procedures and asks for return of nearly $15 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF the election of 2004 is remembered for a great wave of Republican victories, then Connecticut felt the undertow, which tugged the state gently to the left and opened up new majorities in the state Senate and House. Three new seats in the State Senate gave Democrats a super-majority, holding 24 of the 36 seats, enough to override a veto by the Republican governor, M. Jodi Rell. In the House, Democrats also added four members and control 99 seats to 52 for the Republicans. That is just two seats short of the 101 needed for a veto-proof majority.

headline.main: In a Republican World, State Democrats Gain

docs.abstract: Article on gains made by Democrats in Connecticut state Senate and House elections; Democrats, in interviews, talk of bipartisanship rather than mandate; want to reform state tax code and reinstate funding of social programs; vow to shift burden of school funding from local property taxes to state income taxes; photos (L)
docs.snippet: They have a veto-proof majority, but there is no talk of a mandate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cara Marie Egan was married yesterday to Gibson Reynolds III. The Rev. T. Shawn Tracy, a cousin of the bride and a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Patrick's Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. J. Emmett Carroll, a cousin of the bridegroom and also a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony. The bride, 37, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a special-projects administrator with the American College of Physicians, the medical society in Philadelphia. She graduated from Mount St. Mary's College and received a master's degree in health science from Johns Hopkins University.

In another era, it would have seemed normal for a leading British museum to be given art by a wealthy collector. Yet it was a sign of today's very different times that Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate, was seen to score a major coup when he recently persuaded two dozen British artists to donate works from their studios to fill holes in the Tate's contemporary collections. True, the donors will also benefit: museums remain the gateway to posterity. But Sir Nicholas had something else in mind when he welcomed the ''remarkably generous'' gesture: such is the crisis in government financing for British museums that their acquisitions budgets can no longer match market prices. In the case of the Tate, its buying power is about 5 percent of what it was two decades ago.In this, British museums are hardly alone. Few visitors realize that continental Europe's museums, too, spend much of their time and energy these days begging for money to cover not only acquisitions, but also salaries, conservation and even security guards. And they are doing so as government cultural budgets are being squeezed across the region.

headline.main: European Museums Open Door to Corporate Donors

docs.abstract: Article on major European museums, faced with tight budgets and lower government spending, that are seeking corporate sponsorship and cost-sharing; European cultural officials view corporate sponsorship of arts somehow tainted rather than altruistic; American museum directors, on other hand, often speak enviously of Europe's enormous government subsidies; while European museums are ready to welcome private money, they are not eager to surrender any autonomy or follow 'Anglo-Saxon' model of naming new extensions or galleries after generous donors; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Struggling to keep their doors open, some European museums are taking the controversial step of pursuing corporate sponsorship.

docs.lead_paragraph: US Airways asked a bankruptcy court yesterday to throw out contracts covering passenger service agents, flight attendants, mechanics and other workers and replace them with less-expensive ones. The airline also said it wanted to terminate its remaining traditional pension plans and replace them with cheaper retirement benefits like a 401(k) plan. It also plans to reduce substantially or eliminate health care coverage for retirees.

headline.main: US Air Asks Court to End Labor Contracts

docs.abstract: US Airways asks bankruptcy court to throw out contracts covering passenger service agents, flight attendants, mechanics and other workers in favor of less expensive arrangements; also seeks to replace remaining traditional pension plans with cheaper benefits like 401(k) plans, all with goal of saving $1.3 billion a year (M)
docs.snippet: US Airways asked to throw out contracts covering passenger service agents, flight attendants and other workers and replace them with less-expensive ones.
